  <resource src="ltx-amsart.css" type="text/css"/>
  <title>Physical measures for nonlinear random walks on interval</title>
  <creator role="author">
    <personname>V. Kleptsyn</personname>
    <contact role="address">Victor Kleptsyn
<break/><text class="ltx_phantom">iii</text> CNRS, Institut de Recherche Mathematique de Rennes (IRMAR, UMR 6625 CNRS)</contact>
    <contact role="email">Victor.Kleptsyn@univ-rennes1.fr</contact>
  </creator>
  <creator before=" and " role="author">
    <personname>D. Volk</personname>
    <contact role="address">Denis Volk
<break/><text class="ltx_phantom">iii</text> University of Rome “Tor Vergata”
<break/><text class="ltx_phantom">iii</text> Institute for Information Transmission Problems, Russian Academy of Sciences</contact>
    <contact role="email">volk@mat.uniroma2.it</contact>
  </creator>
  <abstract name="Abstract.">
    <p>A one-dimensional confined Nonlinear Random Walk is a tuple of <Math mode="inline" tex="N" text="N" xml:id="m1">
        <XMath>
          <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">N</XMTok>
        </XMath>
      </Math> diffeomorphisms of the unit interval driven by a probabilistic Markov chain. For generic such walks, we obtain a geometric characterization of their ergodic stationary measures and prove that all of them have negative Lyapunov exponents.</p>
    <p>These measures appear to be probabilistic manifestations of physical measures for certain deterministic dynamical systems. These systems are step skew products over transitive subshifts of finite type (topological Markov chains) with the unit interval fiber.</p>
    <p>For such skew products, we show there exist only finite collection of alternating attractors and repellers; we also give a sharp upper bound for their number. Each of them is a graph of a continuous map from the base to the fiber defined almost everywhere w.r.t. any ergodic Markov measure in the base. The orbits starting between the adjacent attractor and repeller tend to the attractor as <Math mode="inline" tex="t\to+\infty" text="t to + infinity" xml:id="m2">
        <XMath>
          <XMApp>
            <XMTok name="to" role="ARROW">→</XMTok>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">t</XMTok>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="plus" role="ADDOP">+</XMTok>
              <XMTok meaning="infinity" name="infty" role="ID">∞</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMApp>
        </XMath>
      </Math>, and to the repeller as <Math mode="inline" tex="t\to-\infty" text="t to - infinity" xml:id="m3">
        <XMath>
          <XMApp>
            <XMTok name="to" role="ARROW">→</XMTok>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">t</XMTok>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="minus" role="ADDOP">-</XMTok>
              <XMTok meaning="infinity" name="infty" role="ID">∞</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMApp>
        </XMath>
      </Math>. The attractors support ergodic hyperbolic physical measures.</p>
  </abstract>
  <keywords name="Key words and phrases">Random walks, stationary measures, dynamical systems, attractors, partial hyperbolicity, skew products</keywords>
  <classification name="2010 Mathematics Subject Classification" scheme="2010 Mathematics Subject Classification">Primary: 82B41, 82C41, 60G50. Secondary: 37C05, 37C20, 37C70, 37D45</classification>
  <acknowledgements>V. K. was supported in part by grants RFBR 10-01-00739, RFBR/CNRS 10-01-93115</acknowledgements>
  <acknowledgements>D. V. was supported in part by grants RFBR 10-01-00739, RFBR/CNRS 10-01-93115, President’s of Russia MK-2790.2011.1 and MK-7567.2013.1, PRIN, “Young SISSA Scientists”, RFBR 12-01-31241-mol_a, RFBR 13-01-00969-a</acknowledgements>
<!--  %**** String Line 25 **** -->  <section inlist="toc" labels="LABEL:sec:intro" xml:id="S1">
    <tags>
      <tag>1</tag>
      <tag role="refnum">1</tag>
      <tag role="typerefnum">§1</tag>
    </tags>
    <title><tag close=". ">1</tag>Introduction</title>
    <toctitle><tag close=" ">1</tag>Introduction</toctitle>
    <subsection inlist="toc" xml:id="S1.SS1">
      <tags>
        <tag>1.1</tag>
        <tag role="refnum">1.1</tag>
        <tag role="typerefnum">§1.1</tag>
      </tags>
      <title><tag close=". ">1.1</tag>Nonlinear Random Walks</title>
      <toctitle><tag close=" ">1.1</tag>Nonlinear Random Walks</toctitle>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS1.p1">
        <p>The classical one-dimensional discrete-time random walk on the real line is the process when every time you toss a coin and make a jump left or right at one unit depending on the toss outcome.</p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS1.p2">
        <p>In this paper, we consider a far generalization of this construction. First, we allow more than two kinds of jumps, and let them depend on the previous jump. In other words, we let the jumps to be driven by a Markov chain with finitely many states. Second, we let the jumps to depend on the current position on the real line, and do this in a nonlinear way. From the point <Math mode="inline" tex="x" text="x" xml:id="S1.SS1.p2.m1">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">x</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math> you make a jump to the point <Math mode="inline" tex="f_{i}(x)" text="f _ i * x" xml:id="S1.SS1.p2.m2">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">f</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">i</XMTok>
                </XMApp>
                <XMDual>
                  <XMRef idref="S1.SS1.p2.m2.1"/>
                  <XMWrap>
                    <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.SS1.p2.m2.1">x</XMTok>
                    <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                  </XMWrap>
                </XMDual>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math>, where <Math mode="inline" tex="f_{i}" text="f _ i" xml:id="S1.SS1.p2.m3">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">f</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">i</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> are some
diffeomorphisms of the real line. Finally, we make a very important assumption which will play through all the paper: that the whole process is confined within a unit interval of the real line.</p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS1.p3">
        <p>In these very general settings we study the probabilistic stationary measures of such processes. It turns out that for a generic process of this kind, there exist only finitely many ergodic stationary measures, and we give a sharp estimate on their number. Their geometry and relative positions on the unit interval can be described in terms of fixed points of the jump maps, see Theorem <ref labelref="LABEL:t:random"/>. Moreover, their Lyapunov exponents are always negative, so the orbits converge on average for almost every random itinerary.</p>
      </para>
<!--  %**** String Line 50 **** -->    </subsection>
    <subsection inlist="toc" xml:id="S1.SS2">
      <tags>
        <tag>1.2</tag>
        <tag role="refnum">1.2</tag>
        <tag role="typerefnum">§1.2</tag>
      </tags>
      <title><tag close=". ">1.2</tag>Skew products</title>
      <toctitle><tag close=" ">1.2</tag>Skew products</toctitle>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS2.p1">
        <p>Random walks have their deterministic twins, namely, the step skew product dynamical systems over topological Markov chains (subshifts of finite type), see Definition <ref labelref="LABEL:d:step_and_mild"/>.
In our setting, these are skew products whose fibers are unit intervals, and fiber maps are <Math mode="inline" tex="C^{1}" text="C ^ 1" xml:id="S1.SS2.p1.m1">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">C</XMTok>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math>-diffeomorphisms onto the image.</p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS2.p2">
        <p>In the dynamical version of our main theorem we show that the dynamics of a generic step skew product with interval fibers can be described in relatively simple terms. This dynamics is in a sense similar to the cartesian product of the dynamics in the base and the dynamics of a single interval diffeomorphism. More precisely (see Theorem <ref labelref="LABEL:t:markov_classification"/>), the phase space of such a skew product can be covered by finitely many absorbing and expelling strips. Any absorbing strip contains a unique attractor; any expelling strip contains a unique repeller. These attractors and repellers are <text class="ltx_emph" font="italic">bony graphs</text> of maps from the base to the fiber: each of them intersects almost every fiber (w.r.t. the Markov measure in the base) at a single point; other fibers are intersected at intervals. This feature is similar to <text class="ltx_emph" font="italic">porcupine horseshoes</text> discovered by Díaz and Gelfert in <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Diaz2012" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>. In particular, we partially answer Question 1.6 from <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Diaz2012" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> by showing that generically, the set of bones is meager. Almost every point of the phase space (w.r.t. the <text class="ltx_emph" font="italic">standard measure</text> which is the product of the Markov measure in the base and Lebesgue measure in the fiber, sf. Definition <ref labelref="LABEL:d:std"/>) tends to one of the attractor graphs. When the time is reversed, almost every point either tends to one of the repeller graphs, or is eventually taken to a domain where the inverse map is not defined.</p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS2.p3">
        <p>Finally, the closure of each attractor graph and of each repeller graph is the support of an ergodic invariant measure that projects to the Markov measure in the base. The attractor measures are physical (SRB); their basins of attraction contain subsets of full standard measure in the corresponding strips. The fiberwise Lyapunov exponents of the attracting and the repelling measures are strictly negative and strictly positive, respectively.</p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS2.p4">
        <p>In <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Kudryashov2010" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>, Kudryashov has recently constructed a robust example of a step skew product with interval fibers such that its attractor intersects some fibers at intervals (instead of points). The set of such fibers has continuum cardinality (in fact, it has a Cantor subset). Thus it is not possible to prove the stronger statement that the attractors and repellers intersect each fiber at a single point only.</p>
      </para>
    </subsection>
    <subsection inlist="toc" xml:id="S1.SS3">
      <tags>
        <tag>1.3</tag>
        <tag role="refnum">1.3</tag>
        <tag role="typerefnum">§1.3</tag>
      </tags>
      <title><tag close=". ">1.3</tag>Background and motivations</title>
      <toctitle><tag close=" ">1.3</tag>Background and motivations</toctitle>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS3.p1">
        <p>There are important reasons to study the associated skew product dynamical systems on their own, too. We provide a brief review below.</p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS3.p2">
        <p>Among the dynamical systems, the open set of hyperbolic ones (also known as Axiom A) is the best understood. For them, Smale’s Spectral Decomposition theorem <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Smale1967a" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> allows one to split the non-wandering set into a finite collection of locally maximal hyperbolic sets. These unit sets admit finite Markov partitions and, therefore, symbolic encodings. If any of them is an attractor, then it also carries an SRB (physical) measure <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Sinai1972" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>, <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Ruelle1976" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>, <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Bowen2008" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>. Thus the hyperbolic systems have both good dynamical and statistical descriptions.</p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS3.p3">
        <p>From the works of Abraham, Smale <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Abraham1970" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> and Newhouse <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Newhouse1974" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> we know that Axiom A is not dense in <Math mode="inline" tex="\dim\geq 2" text="dimension &gt;= 2" xml:id="S1.SS3.p3.m1">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
                <XMTok meaning="dimension" role="LIMITOP">dim</XMTok>
                <XMTok meaning="2" role="NUMBER">2</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math>. So the next step to understand generic systems is to consider partially hyperbolic (PH) ones <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Hasselblatt2006" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>. The skew products over hyperbolic sets provide important examples of PH dynamics. Their central bundles are
tangent to the fibers.
What makes it worthy to consider the PH skew products is that by Hirsch–Pugh–Shub <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="HPS1977" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> theory, the systems <text class="ltx_emph" font="italic">conjugated</text> to such skew products form an open subset in PH. So such skew products are in a sense locally generic.</p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS3.p4">
        <p>The Markov encoding of the base reduces them to the skew products over subshifts of finite type, see Definition <ref labelref="LABEL:d:skpr"/>. The simplest skew products which correspond to <Math mode="inline" tex="\dim E^{c}=1" text="dimension@(E ^ c) = 1" xml:id="S1.SS3.p4.m1">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="equals" role="RELOP">=</XMTok>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok meaning="dimension" role="LIMITOP">dim</XMTok>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">E</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">c</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                </XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> have one-dimensional fibers. There is the single compact one-dimensional manifold without boundary, the circle <Math mode="inline" tex="S^{1}" text="S ^ 1" xml:id="S1.SS3.p4.m2">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">S</XMTok>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math>, and the single one with boundary, the interval <Math mode="inline" tex="I=[0,1]" text="I = closed-interval@(0, 1)" xml:id="S1.SS3.p4.m3">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="equals" role="RELOP">=</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">I</XMTok>
                <XMDual>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok meaning="closed-interval"/>
                    <XMRef idref="S1.SS3.p4.m3.1"/>
                    <XMRef idref="S1.SS3.p4.m3.2"/>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMWrap>
                    <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">[</XMTok>
                    <XMTok meaning="0" role="NUMBER" xml:id="S1.SS3.p4.m3.1">0</XMTok>
                    <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                    <XMTok meaning="1" role="NUMBER" xml:id="S1.SS3.p4.m3.2">1</XMTok>
                    <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">]</XMTok>
                  </XMWrap>
                </XMDual>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math>. As we already mentioned, the present work deals with skew products whose fibers are unit intervals.</p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS3.p5">
        <p>Skew products are also widely used as a tool for the construction of (robust) examples of complicated behavior: convergence of orbits coexisting with minimality <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Antonov1984,Kleptsyn2004" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>, non-removable zero Lyapunov exponents <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="GIKN2005" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>, attractors with intermingled basins <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Kan1994,Bonifant2008,Ilyashenko2008" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>, multidimensional robust non-hyperbolic attractors <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Viana1997" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>, and others. So it is very desirable to obtain a description of their dynamics.
<!--  %**** String Line 75 **** --></p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS3.p6">
        <p>To date, more attention has been paid to skew products with circle fibers than to those with interval fibers. The skew products with circle fibers turned out to exhibit some effects that cannot be observed for a single generic circle diffeomorphism. In his paper <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Antonov1984" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>, Antonov proved that in an open set of step skew products (see Definition <ref labelref="LABEL:d:step_and_mild"/>) with circle fibers the fiberwise coordinates of almost all orbits with the same base coordinate approach each other. Later in <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Kleptsyn2004" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>, this effect was re-discovered by Kleptsyn and Nalski in the following terms. A generic step skew product with circle fibers may have a measurable “attracting” section, which is fiberwise approached by orbits of almost every point. At the same time the section is dense in the phase space. This construction was generalized to the case of mild (not necessarily step) skew products by Homburg in <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Homburg2010" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>. Recall that the orbits of a single circle diffeomorphism either are dense (irrational rotation number) or tend to attracting periodic points (rational rotation number). The examples <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Antonov1984" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>, <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Kleptsyn2004" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>, <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Homburg2010" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> exhibit a mixture of these two types of behavior.</p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS3.p7">
        <p>The dynamical properties of generic diffeomorphisms of closed manifolds are known to be different from those of generic dissipative diffeomorphisms (that is, diffeomorphisms onto the image of a compact manifold with boundary) in the same dimension. For instance, a generic diffeomorphism of an interval has a finite number of fixed points. Any other point tends toward a fixed point. On the other hand, minimal diffeomorphisms of a circle are (metrically) generic.
This difference in behavior motivates us to go from studying skew products with circle fibers
to skew products with interval fibers.</p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS3.p8">
        <p>Note that each skew product with interval fibers can be extended to a skew product with circle fibers. Namely, think of each interval fiber as of an arc of a circle and extend fiber maps to be circle diffeomorphisms. The simplest way to do it is to put a repelling fixed point at the complement to the arc. The resulting skew product with circle fibers can be made the same regularity of the fiber maps and the dependency of the fibers on the base as the initial interval skew product. Thus our result also describes the dynamics of an open (not dense) set of circle skew products.</p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS3.p9">
        <p>In fact, our results are valid not only for the Markov measures but for a wider class of shift-invariant measures. The only condition we really need is stated in Proposition <ref labelref="LABEL:p:measure_property"/>. Roughly speaking, it says that for any fixed “right tail” <Math mode="inline" tex="(\om_{1},\dots,\om_{n},\dots)" text="vector@([\om] _ 1, dots, [\om] _ n, dots)" xml:id="S1.SS3.p9.m1">
            <XMath>
              <XMDual>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok meaning="vector"/>
                  <XMRef idref="S1.SS3.p9.m1.3"/>
                  <XMRef idref="S1.SS3.p9.m1.1"/>
                  <XMRef idref="S1.SS3.p9.m1.4"/>
                  <XMRef idref="S1.SS3.p9.m1.2"/>
                </XMApp>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMApp xml:id="S1.SS3.p9.m1.3">
                    <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                    <ERROR class="undefined">\om</ERROR>
                    <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                  <XMTok name="dots" role="ID" xml:id="S1.SS3.p9.m1.1">…</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                  <XMApp xml:id="S1.SS3.p9.m1.4">
                    <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                    <ERROR class="undefined">\om</ERROR>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                  <XMTok name="dots" role="ID" xml:id="S1.SS3.p9.m1.2">…</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMath>
          </Math> of the symbolic sequence in the base, the conditional probability to see any allowed symbol <Math mode="inline" tex="p_{j}" text="p _ j" xml:id="S1.SS3.p9.m2">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">p</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">j</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> at the position <Math mode="inline" tex="\om_{0}" text="[\om] _ 0" xml:id="S1.SS3.p9.m3">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <ERROR class="undefined">\om</ERROR>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="0" role="NUMBER">0</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> is bounded from zero.</p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS3.p10">
        <p>Similar statements also hold for generic <text class="ltx_emph" font="italic">mild</text> (see Definition <ref labelref="LABEL:d:step_and_mild"/>) skew products with interval fibers; however, the genericity conditions must be changed. The proofs for this case require ideas beyond the present work, and we intend to present them in a separate paper.</p>
      </para>
    </subsection>
    <subsection inlist="toc" xml:id="S1.SS4">
      <tags>
        <tag>1.4</tag>
        <tag role="refnum">1.4</tag>
        <tag role="typerefnum">§1.4</tag>
      </tags>
      <title><tag close=". ">1.4</tag>Remark</title>
      <toctitle><tag close=" ">1.4</tag>Remark</toctitle>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS4.p1">
        <p>In this paper we always assume that the fiberwise maps preserve the orientation of the unit interval. When this is not the case, our results can be derived as follows. Pass to the orientation-preserving covering. Namely, take two copies of the set of Markov states, marked with <text font="bold">+</text> and <text font="bold">-</text>. The orientation-preserving fiber maps take <text font="bold">+</text> to <text font="bold">+</text> and <text font="bold">-</text> to <text font="bold">-</text>. The orientation-changing fiber maps take <text font="bold">+</text> to <text font="bold">-</text> and <text font="bold">-</text> to <text font="bold">+</text>. Then our main result can be applied. After that we project the attractors and repellers back to the initial space.</p>
      </para>
    </subsection>
    <subsection inlist="toc" xml:id="S1.SS5">
      <tags>
        <tag>1.5</tag>
        <tag role="refnum">1.5</tag>
        <tag role="typerefnum">§1.5</tag>
      </tags>
      <title><tag close=". ">1.5</tag>Outline of the paper</title>
      <toctitle><tag close=" ">1.5</tag>Outline of the paper</toctitle>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS5.p1">
        <p>The proof of our main result, Theorem <ref labelref="LABEL:t:random"/>, is based on the link between the dynamics of skew products over one- and two-sided Markov shifts and the corresponding random dynamics on the interval.
<!--  %**** String Line 100 **** --></p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS5.p2">
        <p>In Sections <ref labelref="LABEL:s:markov_def"/> and <ref labelref="LABEL:s:one-sided"/> we recall some standard definitions, introduce the geometrical structures we need later, and state our main result for skew products, Theorem <ref labelref="LABEL:t:markov_classification"/>. In Section <ref labelref="LABEL:s:random_markov"/> we define random dynamics associated with step skew products. At the end of this section, we state the main result of the paper, Theorem <ref labelref="LABEL:t:random"/>. This theorem describes the stationary measures of such random dynamics. In these two sections, an experienced reader can skip everything but the statements of the theorems.</p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S1.SS5.p3">
        <p>In Section <ref labelref="LABEL:s:typicalness"/> we give genericity conditions for Theorem <ref labelref="LABEL:t:markov_classification"/> and Theorem <ref labelref="LABEL:t:random"/>. Sections <ref labelref="LABEL:s:proof"/> and <ref labelref="LABEL:s:bax"/> are devoted to the proof of Theorem <ref labelref="LABEL:t:random"/>: as we have already mentioned, this proof is based on the link between the skew products and the corresponding random dynamics (cf. Lemmas <ref labelref="LABEL:l:absorb"/>, <ref labelref="LABEL:l:MFixed"/>, <ref labelref="LABEL:l:Markov-intervals"/>, <ref labelref="LABEL:l:Markov-uniqueness"/>). Finally, in Section <ref labelref="LABEL:s:proof_markov_classif"/> we deduce Theorem <ref labelref="LABEL:t:markov_classification"/> from Theorem <ref labelref="LABEL:t:random"/>.</p>
      </para>
    </subsection>
  </section>
  <section inlist="toc" labels="LABEL:d:continuous-bony LABEL:d:skpr LABEL:d:std LABEL:d:step_and_mild LABEL:def:compare LABEL:def:compare-bony LABEL:def:drift_up LABEL:def:strip LABEL:p:thin_conj LABEL:r:finite_step LABEL:r:monot_move LABEL:s:markov_def LABEL:t:markov_classification" xml:id="S2">
    <tags>

      <tag role="typerefnum">§2</tag>
    </tags>
    <title><tag close=". ">2</tag>Definitions and <ERROR class="undefined">\hyperref</ERROR>[t:markov_classification]the main theorem about skew products</title>
    <toctitle><tag close=" ">2</tag>Definitions and <ERROR class="undefined">\hyperref</ERROR>[t:markov_classification]the main theorem about skew products</toctitle>
    <para xml:id="S2.p1">
      <p>Suppose <Math mode="inline" tex="\sigma\colon\Sigma\to\Sigma" text="sigma colon Sigma to Sigma" xml:id="S2.p1.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok name="colon" role="METARELOP">:</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" name="sigma" role="UNKNOWN">σ</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok name="to" role="ARROW">→</XMTok>
                <XMTok name="Sigma" role="UNKNOWN">Σ</XMTok>
                <XMTok name="Sigma" role="UNKNOWN">Σ</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is a transitive subshift of finite type (a topological Markov chain) with a finite set of states <Math mode="inline" tex="\{1,\ldots,N\}" text="set@(1, ldots, N)" xml:id="S2.p1.m2">
          <XMath>
            <XMDual>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="set"/>
                <XMRef idref="S2.p1.m2.1"/>
                <XMRef idref="S2.p1.m2.2"/>
                <XMRef idref="S2.p1.m2.3"/>
              </XMApp>
              <XMWrap>
                <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">{</XMTok>
                <XMTok meaning="1" role="NUMBER" xml:id="S2.p1.m2.1">1</XMTok>
                <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                <XMTok name="ldots" role="ID" xml:id="S2.p1.m2.2">…</XMTok>
                <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.p1.m2.3">N</XMTok>
                <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">}</XMTok>
              </XMWrap>
            </XMDual>
          </XMath>
        </Math> and <Math mode="inline" tex="A=(a_{ij})_{i,j=1}^{N}" text="A = (a _ (i * j) _ (list@(i, j) = 1)) ^ N" xml:id="S2.p1.m3">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="equals" role="RELOP">=</XMTok>

                  <XMDual>
                    <XMRef idref="S2.p1.m3.3"/>
                    <XMWrap>
                      <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                      <XMApp xml:id="S2.p1.m3.3">
                        <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                        <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">a</XMTok>
                        <XMApp>

                        </XMApp>

                      <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                    </XMWrap>
                  </XMDual>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="equals" role="RELOP">=</XMTok>
                    <XMDual>
                      <XMApp>
                        <XMTok meaning="list"/>
                        <XMRef idref="S2.p1.m3.1"/>
                        <XMRef idref="S2.p1.m3.2"/>
                      </XMApp>
                      <XMWrap>
                        <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.p1.m3.1">i</XMTok>
                        <XMTok fontsize="70%" role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                        <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.p1.m3.2">j</XMTok>
                      </XMWrap>
                    </XMDual>
                    <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                </XMApp>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">N</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is the transition matrix of <Math mode="inline" tex="\sigma" text="sigma" xml:id="S2.p1.m4">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" name="sigma" role="UNKNOWN">σ</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>, where <Math mode="inline" tex="a_{ij}\in\{0,1\}" text="a _ (i * j) element-of set@(0, 1)" xml:id="S2.p1.m5">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">a</XMTok>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">i</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">j</XMTok>
                </XMApp>
              </XMApp>
              <XMDual>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok meaning="set"/>
                  <XMRef idref="S2.p1.m5.1"/>
                  <XMRef idref="S2.p1.m5.2"/>
                </XMApp>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">{</XMTok>
                  <XMTok meaning="0" role="NUMBER" xml:id="S2.p1.m5.1">0</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                  <XMTok meaning="1" role="NUMBER" xml:id="S2.p1.m5.2">1</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">}</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>. Recall that <Math mode="inline" tex="\Sigma" text="Sigma" xml:id="S2.p1.m6">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok name="Sigma" role="UNKNOWN">Σ</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is the set of all bilateral sequences <Math mode="inline" tex="\omega=(\omega_{n})_{-\infty}^{+\infty}" text="omega = (omega _ n _ (- infinity)) ^ (+ infinity)" xml:id="S2.p1.m7">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="equals" role="RELOP">=</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" name="omega" role="UNKNOWN">ω</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                  <XMDual>
                    <XMRef idref="S2.p1.m7.1"/>
                    <XMWrap>
                      <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                      <XMApp xml:id="S2.p1.m7.1">
                        <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                        <XMTok font="italic" name="omega" role="UNKNOWN">ω</XMTok>
                        <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
                      </XMApp>
                      <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                    </XMWrap>
                  </XMDual>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="minus" role="ADDOP">-</XMTok>
                    <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="infinity" name="infty" role="ID">∞</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                </XMApp>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="plus" role="ADDOP">+</XMTok>
                  <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="infinity" name="infty" role="ID">∞</XMTok>
                </XMApp>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> composed of symbols <Math mode="inline" tex="1,\ldots,N" text="list@(1, ldots, N)" xml:id="S2.p1.m8">
          <XMath>
            <XMDual>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="list"/>
                <XMRef idref="S2.p1.m8.1"/>
                <XMRef idref="S2.p1.m8.2"/>
                <XMRef idref="S2.p1.m8.3"/>
              </XMApp>
              <XMWrap>
                <XMTok meaning="1" role="NUMBER" xml:id="S2.p1.m8.1">1</XMTok>
                <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                <XMTok name="ldots" role="ID" xml:id="S2.p1.m8.2">…</XMTok>
                <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.p1.m8.3">N</XMTok>
              </XMWrap>
            </XMDual>
          </XMath>
        </Math> such that <Math mode="inline" tex="a_{\om_{n}\om_{n+1}}=1" text="a _ ([\om] _ n * [\om] _ (n + 1)) = 1" xml:id="S2.p1.m9">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="equals" role="RELOP">=</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">a</XMTok>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post3"/>
                    <ERROR class="undefined">\om</ERROR>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="50%" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post3"/>
                    <ERROR class="undefined">\om</ERROR>
                    <XMApp>
                      <XMTok fontsize="50%" meaning="plus" role="ADDOP">+</XMTok>
                      <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="50%" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
                      <XMTok fontsize="50%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
                    </XMApp>
                  </XMApp>
                </XMApp>
              </XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> for any <Math mode="inline" tex="n\in\bbZ" text="n element-of [\bbZ]" xml:id="S2.p1.m10">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
              <ERROR class="undefined">\bbZ</ERROR>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> (see, for instance, <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Katok1995" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>).</p>
    </para>
    <para xml:id="S2.p2">
      <p>The map <Math mode="inline" tex="\sigma" text="sigma" xml:id="S2.p2.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" name="sigma" role="UNKNOWN">σ</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> shifts any sequence <Math mode="inline" tex="\om" text="[\om]" xml:id="S2.p2.m2">
          <XMath>
            <ERROR class="undefined">\om</ERROR>
          </XMath>
        </Math> one step to the left: <Math mode="inline" tex="(\sigma\omega)_{n}=\omega_{n+1}" text="(sigma * omega) _ n = omega _ (n + 1)" xml:id="S2.p2.m3">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="equals" role="RELOP">=</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMDual>
                  <XMRef idref="S2.p2.m3.1"/>
                  <XMWrap>
                    <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                    <XMApp xml:id="S2.p2.m3.1">
                      <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                      <XMTok font="italic" name="sigma" role="UNKNOWN">σ</XMTok>
                      <XMTok font="italic" name="omega" role="UNKNOWN">ω</XMTok>
                    </XMApp>
                    <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                  </XMWrap>
                </XMDual>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMTok font="italic" name="omega" role="UNKNOWN">ω</XMTok>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="plus" role="ADDOP">+</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
                  <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
                </XMApp>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>.
By definition (pf. <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Katok1995" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>), subshift is transitive iff</p>
      <equation xml:id="S2.Ex1">
        <Math mode="display" tex="\exists n\in\bbN\;\forall i,j\;(A^{n})_{ij}&gt;0." text="formulae@(exists@(n) element-of [\bbN] * for-all@(i), j * (A ^ n) _ (i * j) &gt; 0)" xml:id="S2.Ex1.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMDual>
              <XMRef idref="S2.Ex1.m1.1"/>
              <XMWrap>
                <XMDual xml:id="S2.Ex1.m1.1">
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok meaning="formulae"/>
                    <XMRef idref="S2.Ex1.m1.1.1"/>
                    <XMRef idref="S2.Ex1.m1.1.2"/>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMWrap>
                    <XMApp xml:id="S2.Ex1.m1.1.1">
                      <XMTok meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>
                      <XMApp>
                        <XMTok meaning="exists" role="BIGOP">∃</XMTok>
                        <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
                      </XMApp>
                      <XMApp>
                        <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                        <ERROR class="undefined">\bbN</ERROR>
                        <XMApp>
                          <XMTok meaning="for-all" name="forall" role="BIGOP">∀</XMTok>
                          <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">i</XMTok>
                        </XMApp>
                      </XMApp>
                    </XMApp>
                    <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                    <XMApp xml:id="S2.Ex1.m1.1.2">
                      <XMTok meaning="greater-than" role="RELOP">&gt;</XMTok>
                      <XMApp>
                        <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                        <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" rpadding="2.8pt">j</XMTok>
                        <XMApp>
                          <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                          <XMDual>
                            <XMRef idref="S2.Ex1.m1.1.2.1"/>
                            <XMWrap>
                              <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                              <XMApp xml:id="S2.Ex1.m1.1.2.1">
                                <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">A</XMTok>
                                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">n</XMTok>
                              </XMApp>
                              <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                            </XMWrap>
                          </XMDual>
                          <XMApp>
                            <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                            <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">i</XMTok>
                            <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">j</XMTok>
                          </XMApp>
                        </XMApp>
                      </XMApp>
                      <XMTok meaning="0" role="NUMBER">0</XMTok>
                    </XMApp>
                  </XMWrap>
                </XMDual>
                <XMTok role="PERIOD">.</XMTok>
              </XMWrap>
            </XMDual>
          </XMath>
        </Math>
      </equation>
      <p>Transitivity implies the indecomposability of the subshift. Indeed, for any <Math mode="inline" tex="m&gt;0" text="m &gt; 0" xml:id="S2.p2.m4">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="greater-than" role="RELOP">&gt;</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">m</XMTok>
              <XMTok meaning="0" role="NUMBER">0</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> the subshift <Math mode="inline" tex="\sigma^{m}" text="sigma ^ m" xml:id="S2.p2.m5">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMTok font="italic" name="sigma" role="UNKNOWN">σ</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">m</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> with the same states allows one to go from any state to any other in finitely many steps. Thus for any <Math mode="inline" tex="m&gt;0" text="m &gt; 0" xml:id="S2.p2.m6">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="greater-than" role="RELOP">&gt;</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">m</XMTok>
              <XMTok meaning="0" role="NUMBER">0</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> the subshift <Math mode="inline" tex="\sigma^{m}" text="sigma ^ m" xml:id="S2.p2.m7">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMTok font="italic" name="sigma" role="UNKNOWN">σ</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">m</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> cannot be split into two nontrivial subshifts of finite type.</p>
    </para>
    <para xml:id="S2.p3">
      <p>We endow <Math mode="inline" tex="\Sigma" text="Sigma" xml:id="S2.p3.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok name="Sigma" role="UNKNOWN">Σ</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> with a metric defined by the formula</p>
      <equation labels="LABEL:e:markov_metric" xml:id="S2.E1">
        <tags>
          <tag>(1)</tag>
          <tag role="refnum">1</tag>
        </tags>
        <Math mode="display" tex="d(\om^{1},\om^{2})=\begin{cases}2^{-\min\{|n|\,:\,\om_{n}^{1}\neq\om_{n}^{2}\}%&#10;},&amp;\om^{1}\neq\om^{2},\\&#10;0,&amp;\om^{1}=\om^{2},\end{cases}\qquad\om^{1},\om^{2}\in\Sigma." text="formulae@(d * open-interval@([\om] ^ 1, [\om] ^ 2) = list@(cases@(2 ^ (- minimum@(absolute-value@(n) colon ([\om] _ n) ^ 1 not-equals ([\om] _ n) ^ 2)), [\om] ^ 1 not-equals [\om] ^ 2, 0, [\om] ^ 1 = [\om] ^ 2), [\om] ^ 1), [\om] ^ 2 element-of Sigma)" xml:id="S2.E1.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMDual>
              <XMRef idref="S2.E1.m1.6"/>
              <XMWrap>
                <XMDual xml:id="S2.E1.m1.6">
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok meaning="formulae"/>
                    <XMRef idref="S2.E1.m1.6.1"/>
                    <XMRef idref="S2.E1.m1.6.2"/>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMWrap>
                    <XMApp xml:id="S2.E1.m1.6.1">
                      <XMTok meaning="equals" role="RELOP">=</XMTok>
                      <XMApp>
                        <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                        <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">d</XMTok>
                        <XMDual>
                          <XMApp>
                            <XMTok meaning="open-interval"/>
                            <XMRef idref="S2.E1.m1.6.1.1"/>
                            <XMRef idref="S2.E1.m1.6.1.2"/>
                          </XMApp>
                          <XMWrap>
                            <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                            <XMApp xml:id="S2.E1.m1.6.1.1">
                              <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                              <ERROR class="undefined">\om</ERROR>
                              <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
                            </XMApp>
                            <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                            <XMApp xml:id="S2.E1.m1.6.1.2">
                              <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                              <ERROR class="undefined">\om</ERROR>
                              <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="2" role="NUMBER">2</XMTok>
                            </XMApp>
                            <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                          </XMWrap>
                        </XMDual>
                      </XMApp>
                      <XMDual>
                        <XMApp>
                          <XMTok meaning="list"/>
                          <XMRef idref="S2.E1.m1.5"/>
                          <XMRef idref="S2.E1.m1.6.1.3"/>
                        </XMApp>
                        <XMWrap>
                          <XMDual xml:id="S2.E1.m1.5">
                            <XMApp>

    <para xml:id="S2.p5">
      <p>A <text class="ltx_emph" font="italic">skew product</text> over a subshift of finite type <Math mode="inline" tex="(\Sigma,\sigma)" text="open-interval@(Sigma, sigma)" xml:id="S2.p5.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMDual>
              <XMApp>

              </XMApp>
              <XMWrap>

              </XMWrap>
            </XMDual>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is a dynamical system <Math mode="inline" tex="F\colon\Sigma\times M\to\Sigma\times M" text="F colon Sigma * M to Sigma * M" xml:id="S2.p5.m2">
          <XMath>

                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">×</XMTok>

                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">M</XMTok>
                </XMApp>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">×</XMTok>

                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">M</XMTok>
                </XMApp>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> of the form</p>

      </equation>
      <p>where <Math mode="inline" tex="\om\in\Sigma" text="[\om] element-of Sigma" xml:id="S2.p5.m3">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>
              <ERROR class="undefined">\om</ERROR>

            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>, and the map <Math mode="inline" tex="f_{\om}(x)\in\DiffIm^{1}(M)" text="f _ [\om] * x element-of [\DiffIm] ^ 1 * M" xml:id="S2.p5.m5">
          <XMath>

              <XMTok meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
